Article Title: Punjab Couple Cloud Space Fraud: Couple made Rs 3,500 crore selling cloud space; remanded in ED custody
Article Text:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: A couple arrested by ED from Punjab on Friday, who had masterminded a multi-level marketing fraud by duping investors with promises of handsome rental value on purchase of cloud space & leasing it back, has been remanded in ED custody.On Saturday, a special PMLA court in Jalandhar remanded Sukhvinder Singh Kharour to 10 days and Dimple Kharour to five days in ED custody. They allegedly collected over Rs 3,500 crore in past 2-3 years and siphoned off the "proceeds of crime".Look out notices were issued after they went underground. At least 26 luxury cars worth Rs 80 crore (belonging to the couple) were seized by ED last month. ED also attached other assets in Punjab, totalling Rs 178 crore."The cloud sale and lease back model was found non-existent to cheat the investors. The proceeds of crime of Rs 3,558 crore (ascertained so far) generated out of criminal activities were diverted by VMSL (Vuenow Marketing Services Ltd) and group companies in giving commission to channel partners, purchase of various luxurious vehicles, gold and diamonds, routing of hundreds of crores through shell entities and further investment in properties," ED said.The accused created multiple shell entities to siphon off proceeds of crime. Huge funds were also diverted into bank accounts of Dimple and to film production units controlled by her, such as Kharour Films LLP, Fruitchaat Entertainment Pvt and Avni ITInfra Ventures Ltd, in which she is a director. However, these companies do not have any relation with the cloud particle business VMSL that collected huge funds from investors, the agency said.ED was on the lookout for the influential couple who had evaded arrest in Punjab for a long time despite several complaints of cheating and fraud. The central agency finally registered an FIR in Noida and with the help of UP Police issued a look out notice. Officials coordinated with international enforcement agencies that helped in tracing the accused in Nepal from where they were sent to India. "Sukhvinder, CEO and founder of Vuenow Group is 'mastermind' of the scam who in connivance with his close aides orchestrated the 'Cloud Particle Scam'," ED said.
Article Summary: Sukhvinder and Dimple Kharour masterminded multi-level marketing fraud. They allegedly collected over Rs 3,500 crore in past 2-3 years. At least 26 luxury cars worth Rs 80 crore (belonging to the couple) were seized by ED last month.

Article Title: 'One moment we were sleeping, the next thrown like puppets': Avalanche survivors recall moment disaster struck
Article Text:
Rescue operations

DEHRADUN: There was no time to run. One moment, the workers were asleep inside their container homes, the bitter cold pressing in from all sides, the hum of the mountains steady and unbroken. Then came a roar - deep, monstrous, growing louder by the second. The earth beneath them shuddered. The walls groaned. And before anyone could move, the avalanche was there, like a sudden apparition in a horror movie.Ganesh Kumar, a road construction worker from Pithoragarh, barely had time to open his eyes before the container was ripped from its place it was pegged and sent tumbling into the snow. "It happened so fast, we had no time to think," he said from his hospital bed in Jyotirmath. "One moment, we were asleep. The next, the entire container was flung ahead, rolling over and over. It must have been 50, maybe 60 metres. We had no control. We were just... thrown... like puppets."Then came the deafening silence. The world outside was gone, above a thick pile of snow. Inside the crumpled container, the men lay tangled, gasping for breath, bodies stiff with cold. "Darkness, silence, and the unbearable cold wrapped around us like a shroud," one of them recalled. "The snow was everywhere - pushing against us, pressing into our chests. We tried shouting, but the sound just died around us. It felt like the snow was swallowing our voices."The hours crawled by, stretching endlessly. The cold bit deep, turning their limbs numb. Some of them tried clawing at the walls, but there was no way out. The air felt thinner. Some stopped talking. "It felt like we were already gone," one survivor said.Then, a noise - faint at first. Footsteps. Voices, muffled through the snow. Hope surged through their bodies like a shock. "At first, I thought I was imagining it," another worker said. "Then the sound got closer, and suddenly, the snow started shifting." Hands broke through the ice, pulling them from the wreckage, dragging them into the open air. "They were our saviours - farishtey (angels)," another survivor said, his voice still trembling at the memory of the Army and ITBP personnel cutting through the snow to reach them. Manoj Bhandari from Uttarkashi district said, "Even now, the memories haunt us - how close we came to being buried forever. Some of our friends didn't make it. That pain... it's not going anywhere."
Article Summary: The workers were asleep inside their container homes when the avalanche struck. "One moment, we were asleep. The next, the entire container was flung ahead, rolling over and over. It must have been 50, maybe 60 metres," one survivor said.

Article Title: NHAI Toll Fee Deduction: False toll fee deduction? NHAI cracks the whip
Article Text: NEW DELHI: Have you ever received a toll deduction message from your FASTag wallet even though your car was parked or you hadn't passed through a toll plaza? "Customers facing false deductions can file a complaint by calling 1033 or emailing falsededuction@ihmcl.com and each case is thoroughly investigated. And if the complaint of such deduction or incorrect manual transactions is established, chargebacks are issued to the customer immediately. Additionally, a Rs 1 lakh penalty is imposed on the toll operator responsible," said a senior IHMCL official.He said, the main reason for such false deductions is entry of incorrect vehicle numbers by toll operators while processing electronic transactions manually.

Article Title: Australian blood donor James Harrison dies at 88: Know more about the man who saved millions with his exceptional blood
Article Text:
James Harrison: Early life and his inspiration to donate blood



James Harrison's blood exceptional quality



James Harrison's humility and family legacy



James Harrison death: Tributes and continuing impact



James Harrison's final days



Australian Blood Donor James Harrison Dies at 88: Learn about his childhood, his high-quality blood and why he became "The Man with the Golden Arm". James Harrison, or the "Man with the Golden Arm" as he was popularly known, died at 88 years old, leaving behind a legacy of philanthropy and medical history that saved thousands of lives. Not only is he most famous for his record-breaking donations of blood, but he is also the man who contributed to the creation of a life-saving treatment that saved millions of babies worldwide as per reports.James Harrison's amazing tale began when he was young at the age of 14. His complex lung operation then required multiple blood transfusions if he was to survive. Harrison's first introduction to blood donation made a deep impression on him and forged an affinity with volunteering that he cherished for the rest of his life. At age 18, motivated by his father, Harrison gave his first blood donation, an act which would lead into more than half a century of volunteering.For an incredible 60 years, Harrison never missed an opportunity to give blood. In his lifetime, he gave plasma 1,173 times, his unwavering commitment to saving lives. He continued to donate until he retired in 2018 at the age of 81, a tribute to his sustained devotion to saving lives.It was the presence of the rare and precious Anti-D antibody in Harrison's plasma that made his blood so special. This antibody has been instrumental in finding a cure for Haemolytic Disease of the Foetus and Newborn (HDFN), a life-threatening condition that could strike babies born to Rh-negative mothers. Harrison's blood donations, which held this special antibody, have been responsible for saving the lives of more than two million babies globally. His donations have had a lasting and widespread impact on medical science, particularly in the field of maternal and child health.In spite of the scale of his success, Harrison was humble all his life. He never felt that any blood donor played a more significant role than him in saving lives and never wanted any special praise for his contributions. Even at times of personal hardship, such as the death of his wife Barbara, who was a committed blood donor herself, Harrison was committed to his cause of helping others.According to BBC reports, Harrison's daughter, Tracey Mellowship, reported that her father wasn't only a humanitarian but also a great father and grandfather with a witty sense of humor. Tracey has a very personal connection to his efforts—she herself was an Anti-D recipient, and her very existence was made possible because of his efforts.James Harrison's death has created a profound void in his family and the medical fraternity. Tributes have flowed in from all over the globe, with Australian blood donation groups declaring him an icon of kindness, selflessness, and commitment to saving lives. His legacy continues to motivate generations of blood donors to come, and his hope was always that someone would eventually break his record.Although Harrison has passed away, his lifesaving legacy remains. Researchers from the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research (WEHI), in association with Lifeblood, are currently engaged in a groundbreaking project titled "James in a Jar". The project seeks to recreate the Anti-D antibody through samples of Harrison's blood to make mass production of the life-saving antibody possible. The idea is to further the availability of the treatment past Australia and save tens of thousands of lives globally, advancing Harrison's own legacy in eliminating HDFN.James Harrison died peacefully in his sleep on February 17, 2025, at Peninsula Village Nursing Home. The unassuming Junee, Australian man's life was characterized by his commitment to saving others' lives. His remarkable efforts left an indelible mark in the world, and though he is no more, his contribution continues to form the future of blood donation and medical research.Harrison's legacy will endure in the lives of those whose lives were saved through his plasma, ongoing research prompted by his generosity, and the generations of individuals who, moved by his example, will donate blood to save others.
Article Summary: Australian blood donor James Harrison has died at the age of 88. Harrison donated plasma 1,173 times in his lifetime, saving thousands of lives. His blood held a rare and precious Anti-D antibody. This antibody has been instrumental in finding a cure for Haemolytic Disease of the Foetus and Newborn.

The growing unrest among investors signals a shift in sentiment, as many once ardent supporters now express skepticism over Musk’s priorities and Tesla’s future.Tesla’s stock has faced significant volatility since the start of 2025, with sharp declines raising concerns among investors.
